title: 107_hr3975
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that HIV/AIDS is predicted to become the worst infectious disease epidemic in history, surpassing past pandemics like the bubonic plague and the 1918 influenza outbreak. Disparities in HIV transmission from mother to child between rich and poor countries are increasing, potentially leading to a significant rise in child mortality by 2010 in the most affected regions. The transmission of HIV from mother to child is increasing, posing a threat to child survival in developing countries. UNAIDS predicts a significant increase in AIDS-related child mortality by 2010 in the most affected regions. The number of AIDS orphans worldwide is expected to triple in the next 10 years, leading to economic decay, social fragmentation, and political destabilization. The global infectious disease threat, particularly HIV/AIDS, could reduce GDP by 20% in some sub-Saharan African nations by 2010. Despite discouraging statistics, countries like Uganda, Senegal, and Thailand have successfully implemented prevention programs to curb HIV infection rates. The global infectious disease threat, particularly HIV/AIDS, could reduce GDP by 20% in some sub-Saharan African nations by 2010. Some developing nations like Uganda, Senegal, and Thailand have successfully implemented prevention programs to curb HIV infection rates. United States financial support for medical research, education, and disease containment as a global strategy has enormous benefits for all Americans. Given the cost of combating AIDS and other infectious diseases worldwide, a contribution to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria is crucial. The proposed Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund, endorsed by the international community in September 1997, has not been implemented due to lack of Congressional authorization. Accepted by 109 out of 110 IMF members, this amendment aims to allocate Special Drawing Rights to combat AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The proposed Fourth Amendment to the International Monetary Fund's Articles of Agreement has not been implemented due to lack of Congressional authorization. It has been accepted by 109 out of 110 IMF members, with the United States holding 17.16% of the voting power. Approval by the US would enable the allocation of Special Drawing Rights. The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria leverages resources from donor nations to combat the HIV/AIDS crisis. The Bretton Woods Agreements Act is amended to accept the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement of the Fund, allowing for the contribution of Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. The United States Governor of the Fund accepts the Fourth Amendment to the Articles of Agreement. The Secretary of the Treasury is instructed to seek an agreement for the Global Fund to hold Special Drawing Rights. Upon achieving the agreement, the Secretary of the Treasury will provide contributions. The Secretary of the Treasury is instructed to seek an agreement for the Global Fund to hold Special Drawing Rights and provide contributions to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria. Additionally, negotiations will be pursued to urge other Fund members to make similar contributions. The Secretary of the Treasury is instructed to negotiate with other Fund members to contribute Special Drawing Rights to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria.
